is a city of about 160,000 located in

.  Founded in 1883 in what was then known as the Dakota Territory, Sioux Falls has grown from a sleepy Midwestern town into a resort for shopping and tourism in the northern Great Plains.  It is widely recognized as the largest urban center between

Sioux Falls may be traveled by car, but also has courier and taxi service, as well as trolley service downtown in the summer.   There is a municipal bus service, but be advised that it shuts down rather early in the evenings.  The Sioux Falls Airport (FSD), 2801 N. Jaycee Lane, is the major airport in the area.  The Sioux Falls Bus Terminal (SXF), 1500 W Russell St, serves virtually the entire continental North America.

Sioux Falls is located at the intersection of two major interstates, I-90 and I-29.  Another interstate, I-229, travels from the southwestern part of the city to the northeastern part.  This forms a loop around the city.
, Travel west on I-90 to Sioux Falls.  Approximate travel time is eight hours.
, Travel east on I-76 into Nebraska until the I-80 interchange.  Merge east onto I-80. Stay east on I-80 until you reach
.  From there, go north on I-29 to Sioux Falls.  Approximate travel time is nine hours.
, Travel north on I-29 to Sioux Falls.  Approximate travel time is five hours.

, Travel south on I-35, and then west on I-90 to Sioux Falls.  Approximate travel time is four hours.  An alternative route would be US Highway 169 southwest of out the western suburbs of Minneapolis.  Travel south on Minnesota State Highway 60, just west of Mankato.  Travel southwest to Worthington, and travel west on I-90 to Sioux Falls.

Once in Sioux Falls, the interstate exits are:

provides bus service into Sioux Falls from a number of U.S. and Canadian cities, including

.  Connections with Greyhound and numerous other bus companies mean Sioux Falls is accessible from anywhere within the continental USA, Canada and Mexico.  Fares range from $50-$200 round-trip, depending on your point of origination.  All buses arrive and depart from the Sioux Falls Bus Depot.

The terminal has been described as one of the nicest in the country - it is clean, comfortable with a tv lounge, internet cafe, souvenir gift store and snack bar.

value: , 1500 W. Russell Street, +1 605-336-0885.  Located within walking distance (less than a half-mile) to the Sioux Falls Arena & Convention Center and the surrounding hotels.

Onward car transportation from the bus station to all parts of SD, IA, and MN from Sioux Falls by Cross Courier & Dispatch +1-800-940-8185

While there is some public transportation in Sioux Falls and taxis are generally available, the easiest way to get around the city is by car.  Roads are generally well-maintained (with the occasional summer road construction) and traffic is quite light by typical North American standards, especially considering the exponential growth of the city.

As mentioned above, Sioux Falls is located at the intersection of I-29 and I-90.  Another interstate, I-229, runs from the southwest to northeast corner of the city, meaning that the vast majority of Sioux Falls is accessible via an interstate.

Most of the major attractions, shopping areas, and dining establishments are located near two major east-west roads - 12th Street and 41st Street.  Minnesota Avenue also has a large selection of restaurants and shopping places.

operates 15 bus routes throughout the city. Fares are $1 for adults with books of 10 available for a 15 percent discount.  

Buses generally run every half-hour during the day, but nearly all routes stop running by 7PM and bus service on weekends is very limited.
There are a handful of taxi services that operate in Sioux Falls.  Fares are reasonable by U.S. standards:

Sioux Falls Transit operates a trolley that operates Monday through Saturday from 10AM-8PM during the summer, and on Saturdays through the fall.  The trolley operates through downtown Sioux Falls from Falls Park to the Washington Pavilion.

The natural wonder that gave Sioux Falls its name, Falls Park offers multiple viewing areas and a brand-new, five-story observation tower.  From there, one can view not only the impressive waterfalls but some of the city's earliest and most historic buildings.

value: content= More than 200 collections dedicated to preserving and interpreting the history and cultures of the Northern Plains. Free admission, but freewill donations are appreciated.
content=Open seven days a week, hours vary. Offers visitors a look at more than 145 mounted specimens of mounted wildlife. Admission is free with a paid admission to the Great Plains Zoo.
content=Displays original art by American Indians from the northern plains.
content=Open daily. A National Historic Landmark that hosts lectures, workshops, children's programs and more. Admission is free.
name=Visual Arts Center at the Washington Pavilion
content= Features multiple exhibits for both adults and children. Most exhibits are free.
content=Open seven days a week, hours vary by season. More than 500 animals, from penguins to tigers to baby rhinos, inhabit the grounds. Admission is $7 for adults, $4 for children ages 3 to 12.

, 11th Street and Main Avenue, +1 605-367-6000. Tu-Th, Sa 10AM-5PM, F 10AM-8PM, Su 12PM-5PM.  Home to more than 80 hands-on science experiences and the giant-screen Cinedome (IMAX) theater.  Admission is $6.75 for adults, $4.60 for children.

content=Open seven days a week, hours vary by season but generally run from 10AM-4PM. View the natural habitat of more than 800 free flying butterflies and other tropical animals. Admission for adults is $6, children under 18 $4.

, 12th Street and Kiwanis Avenue, +1 605-367-7141.  Open Memorial Day to Labor Day, 9AM-5PM seven days a week.  Memorial built to honor the most decorated battleship of World War II.  Admission is free.
content=Renner, SD., ( Open for wine tastings Th-Fri. 12-6PM Sat. 11-5PM October-April; W-F 12-6PM Sat. 11-5PM Sun. 12-4PM May-September.
content=The SDSO is an award winning orchestra whose season spans from Sept to May. They perform in the Great Hall of the Washington Pavilion which is known nationwide for its excellent acoustics.

content=Sertoma Park is a wide open area with a large amount of outdoor activities for all. There is a main part of children containing five incredibly large jungle gyms. There is a large complex right in the middle of the playground areas containing picnic tables, a perfect place for a family with many children to stop and have a snack or even lunch. There are many outdoor trails going throughout and around the park. They are great for bird-watching. The main trail goes by the Big Sioux River, a large grassy field, several ponds and some woods, and ideal trail for outdoor enthusiasts. The Seratoma Park is also home to a large butterfly house that contains both exotic and local butterflies.

Sioux Falls has a surprising range of golf options for a mid-sized city, with courses of varying degrees of difficulty and comparably low greens fees.  It is important to call early for tee times, especially in the spring and early summer.

value: content=18-hole, 6,900-yard championship caliber course located on the outskirts of Sioux Falls. Greens fee for 18 holes range from $19-$27.
content=Public course operated by Sioux Falls Parks Department. Greens fees for 18 holes range from $18-$21.
content=9-hole course perfect for players of all skill levels. Generally the least crowded course in town. Greens fees for 9 holes range from $9-$10.

content=By the far the best public course in town, but the course with the longest waiting list for tee times. Adjacent to an excellent pub and restaurant. Greens fees for 18 holes range from $24-$28.
content=18-hole, 6,500-yard championship course on the east side of Sioux Falls. Privately owned, but open to the public. Green fees $25.50-$29.50 for 18 holes.

There are two other golf courses in town, associated with the Minnehaha Country Club and Westward Ho Country Club, but they are rarely open to non-members.
Sioux Falls is home to a number of professional sports teams that play a variety of sports.

content= Open seven days a week, store hours may vary. Touted as the largest shopping complex between Minneapolis and Denver with over 180 stores, including major department stores like JCPenney, Sears and Macy's. Single-level layout makes walking its entirety a challenge.
name=Falls Park Visitor Information Center & Gift Shop
content=If you need mementos of your time in Sioux Falls, this is the place to go. Another information center and gift shop is in the Empire Mall next to the food court.
content=Closed Tuesdays, otherwise open 10AM-6PM. The best place in town for quality American Indian art.
content=Fair trade items from around the world. Interesting and colorful jewelry, accessories, stationery, decor, and more. Even more beautiful items during the holiday season.

Due to the recent influx of immigrants settling in Sioux Falls, a large number of ethnic restaurants have sprung up throughout the city, offering ethnic Balkan, Italian, Ethiopian and eastern Asian cuisine. You can also find all of the usual chain restaurant suspects (everything from Outback Steakhouse to Olive Garden) the number of remarkable independent restaurants is small.  However, there are a few eateries in the budget (less than $10), mid-range (less than $20) and splurge (more than $20) categories to get you by.

value: directions=One block north of the Washington pavilion
content=Upscale bistro. Varied menu serving lunch and dinner. The best bread in town and great coffee are two bonuses.

content=Located right next to the Empire Mall. Family dining with a fun sports environment. A variety of food, home-made pizza, pasta, burgers, and tons of great appetizers. Join the World Beer Tour and travel the world of beer in just one place, there is 110 to choose from. There is Plasma TV's all around for the sports fan as well as darts, pool, and shuffleboard. Friendly employees who are knowledgeable in all their beers as well as with the menu and will guide you to making the right decision.
content=Bros Brasserie Americano has incredible food and a concise, but brilliant menu for lunch or dinner. Check out their Brunch on Sundays, you will not be disappointed.

content=Open for lunch M-Sa. Located on the first floor of the Washington Pavilion, Leonardo's is famous for its outstanding sandwiches, made-to-order pizzas and Nathan's hot dogs. Downtown location means the place can get quite busy.
content=Formerly the Market Street Diner, this place is an ideal breakfast stop if you're tired of Perkins, IHOP or Denny's. Their malts are top-notch.

content=Hy-vee is a well-known grocery store in the tri-state area however, in each store there is a dining area. The Hy-vee on E. 10th st has a wide- variety of breakfast, lunch, dinner, or dessert options, including Chinese and Italian. Daily specials.
content=Huge portions, flavorful gyros, fast service, and interesting Greek decor.

content=Sioux Falls, SD 57106. Open for lunch and dinner. It's been voted the past 6 years as the best Italian in Sioux Falls. The menu is a mix of modern Italian dishes and old standards. They have a full bar and extensive wine selection. Once a year they have a wine tasting event were they close the restaurant to all but people who buy tickets for a meal plus the tasting. Mains cost around $10-15. On weekends come early or be prepared for a thirty to an hour wait to be seated. The waitresses are very knowledgeable and helpful.
content=Open for lunch and dinner. Small, but the best sushi in town.
content=Open for lunch and dinner. Better-than-average Indian food with a fairly expansive menu.' Next door to the bus terminal.
content=Open seven days a week for lunch and dinner. Has all the trappings of a sports bar, but with a selection of 100 beers and a full menu with everything from prime rib to Buffalo wings.

I-29 @ Exit 73, west to Tea, +1 605-368-9667.  Open for lunch and dinner.  Located on Main Street in Tea (less than ten minutes south of Sioux Falls), this place is considered one of the best steak houses in the area.
content=Open for lunch and dinner M-Sa. Simply the best atmosphere and best food in town. Steaks dominate the menu, but the half-roast duckling and pork filet mignon are outstanding.

content=Open for lunch and dinner, as well as a Sunday Brunch from 9:30AM-1:30PM. Traditional Italian fare, but the real draw are the near-perfect pizzas cooked in a woodburning oven. The Sunday Brunch is a must.

Sioux Falls does sport a variety of nightclub options:

value: content=Open most nights until 2AM. While the bar sports a "roadhouse" theme the crowd is pretty eclectic and you're just as likely to hear top-40 music as country. There's generally no cover except when the bar plays host to occasional live entertainment.
content=Across the street from Poppadox Pub, this bar has the reputation for being a biker hangout in the past.
content=Features live music, a full menu and the only daiquiri bar in Sioux Falls. A second location has opened up on N. West Avenue near the Convention Center.
content=Downtown bar is a Sioux Falls institution.

Accommodations in Sioux Falls are plentiful.  Budget accommodations will generally run less than $60 per night, while a mid-range hotel shouldn't cost more than $100.  Since most hotels cater to business travelers, weekend deals are frequent and it doesn't hurt to call the hotel directly to try to get the best rate.

Sioux Falls is an ideal launching pad for several day trips.

value: The two major state universities in South Dakota. South Dakota State University in
and the University of South Dakota in
are each within an hour's drive on I-29.
Just a few miles west of Sioux Falls on I-90, Buffalo Ridge offers a cowboy ghost town experience.
is approximately one hour west of Sioux Falls on I-90, and is home to several attractions including the world-famous Corn Palace.
are approximately a four-to-five-hour drive west of Sioux Falls, which makes the city a convenient stopping point either going to or coming from that tourist destination.

Palisades State Park is located northeast of Sioux Falls (Exits 406 and 410 off I-90). Buy a day pass into the park and explore the beautiful pink cliffs and rocks. You can even rock climb there if you have your own equipment.
